I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan,  (ii)  a  proposed  grant,  and  (iii)  proposed  administration  of  a  loan  to  be  provided  by  the 
Organization  of  Petroleum  Exporting  Countries  (OPEC)  Fund  for  International  Development 
(OFID) to Nepal for additional financing of the Decentralized Rural Infrastructure and Livelihood 
Project.1 
 
The additional financing is for the current project, which is performing well. The focus is 
2. 
on  improving  rural  transport  connectivity  and  community  infrastructure,  and  uplifting  the 
livelihood of rural communities in 18 poor and remote hill and mountain districts of Nepal.2  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
Nepal  is  a  landlocked  country  situated  between  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  in  the 
3. 
north  and  India  in  the  south,  east,  and  west.  The  road  networks  are  the  major  modes  of 
transportation in the country because of its widespread mountainous terrain and difficult weather 
conditions.  Pervasive  poverty  in  the  hill  and  mountain  districts  is  linked  to  the  lack  of  road 
connectivity  and  corresponding  high  transport  costs,  which  discourage  the  mobility  of  people, 
and  movement  of  goods  and  services  within  and  outside  the  regions.  The  majority  of 
settlements  in hilly  and mountainous  areas  are not  accessible by motorized  vehicles;  they  are 
cut  off  from  the  road  network,  and  thus  face  constraints  of  limited  access  to  food  supplies, 
health  and  education  facilities,  and  other  essential  services.  In  these  areas,  rural  transport  is 
largely based on a trail system of foot trails, mule tracks, and trail bridges. 
 
4. 
Since  1985,  the  Government  of  Nepal  has  made  considerable  progress  in  linking 
important  geographical  areas  of  Nepal  by  road  infrastructure,  aided  by  suitable  policies, 
legislative  enactments,  and  guidelines.  Nepal’s  road  network  increased  by  6.7%  a  year  from 
1995  to  2004,  with  rural  roads  growing  by  11%  a  year.  Despite  this  improvement,  the  rural 
transport infrastructure in the country remains underdeveloped. Only 17% of the rural population 
has access to an all-weather road, compared with 60% in India and 37% in Bangladesh. Road 
density is only 121 as against 1,838 in Bangladesh and 1,116 in India.3 Road density remains 
very low in remote districts in the hills and mountain regions. 
  
In the 18 poor and remote hill and mountain districts4 of Nepal where the overall project 
5. 
will  focus,  poverty  incidence  was  about  41%  in  2004,5 which  is  significantly  higher  than  the 
national level of 30%. This difference is inextricably linked to the lack of accessibility for the rural 
population  in  the  districts.  The  more  distant  the  districts  are  from  the  center,  and  the  more 
mountainous,  the  less  access  people  have  to  social  services,  markets,  and  ultimately 
opportunities  to  enhance  their  economic  activities  and  livelihoods.  The  scope  for  developing

 2 

rural transport infrastructure such as roads, tracks, trail bridges, and ropeways is immense, and 
it requires a major investment in the medium to longer term. Non-transport constraints are also 
part  of  the  broad  accessibility–poverty  nexus.  These  include  (i)  the  lack  of  social  and  market 
facilities,  (ii)  the  lack  of  integrated  accessibility  planning,  and  (iii)  low  income  and  cash 
availability. The situation is aggravated by the persistence of strong inequalities between castes 
and ethnic groups. 
 
6. 
In  Nepal,  the  road  maintenance  program—including  planning  and  implementation—is 
decentralized  at  the  district  level,  with  the  involvement  of  the  road  users.  However,  there  are 
many weaknesses in the approach to rural road maintenance: (i) periodic maintenance is given 
preference  over  routine  maintenance,  (ii)  over  50%  of  the  rural  roads  network  is  in  an 
unmaintainable condition, (iii) maintenance supervision is inadequate, (iv) maintenance budgets 
(covering  only  30%  of  needs)  are  inadequate,  and  (v)  maintenance  skills  and  material 
specifications are poor. 
 
Past  and  ongoing  experiences  in  the  rural  roads  sector  in  Nepal6 provide  key  lessons 
7. 
learned that need to be addressed. These include the following: (i) district administrations lack a 
maintenance  culture  and  have 
road  maintenance; 
(ii) supplementary  infrastructure  is  not  aligned  and  well  focused  with  the  project  accessibility 
core  objective;  (iii)  skills  training  are  not  always  well  focused  and market-driven;  (iv)  transport 
services are unreliable and expensive; (v) more works tend to be allocated to contractors than 
to  communities;  (vi)  subproject  planning,  appraisal,  and  works  procurement  are  too  slow;  (vii) 
districts  have  weak  implementation  capacity  and  a  skills  shortage;  (viii)  attention  is  lacking 
regarding  the  needs  of  poor  and  excluded7 groups  including  women,  excluded  ethnic  groups, 
and victims of the past conflict; and (ix) access of the rural poor to microfinance is lacking. 
 
8. 
The  project  is  included  in  the  country  partnership  strategy  for  2010–2012  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), which supports the country’s peace and development aspirations by 
promoting broad-based and inclusive economic growth.8 The overall project will help strengthen 
peace building directly through improved access in remote districts, thereby improving access to 
health  and  education,  enhancing  opportunity  for  skills  and  employment  for  income,  and 
establishing  linkages  within  remote  geographic  locations. 9 This  can  help  in  delivering  long-
anticipated public expectations in the form of peace dividends in the post- conflict environment 
in  the  country.  The  project  is  also  aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2020,  which  advocates  rural 
infrastructure development. 10 
 
9. 
Despite  weaknesses  in  the  approach  to  the  rural  road  sector,  the  current  project, 
approved  on  24  September  2004  continues  to  show  good  performance  and  implementation 
progress has been satisfactory (or better) in regard to achievement of outcome and outputs, and 
compliance with covenants. The current project design has demonstrated good resilience to the

 numerous changes in the country’s political and security situation, and has contributed to peace 
building  through  widened  social  and  economic  opportunities  for  the  poor  in  remote  districts. 
Constructing  community  infrastructure—including  drinking  water  schemes,  micro-hydropower 
schemes,  and  health  and  education  facilities—helped  in  restoring  rural  livelihoods.  These 
community infrastructures are functioning well and are likely to be sustainable because they are 
demand-driven,  with  community  participation  in  operation  and  maintenance.  In  the  current 
project impact zone, between 2007 and 2010, household income rose by 57% against the target 
of  25%,  while  road freight  volume  increased  by 96%  against  the  target of  100%.11 By  30  April 
2011,  381  kilometers  (km)  of  roads  were  constructed  or  rehabilitated  (70%  of  the  revised 
target);  trail  bridges  with  a  length  of  8,430  meters  (m)  were  completed  (against  the  7,000  m 
target).    The  current  project  has  already  created  more  than  5.3  million  person-days  of  jobs 
(more than 70% from poor and excluded groups). 
  
10. 
Progress  has  been  good  in  the  implementation  of  the  gender  design  features  and 
gender action plan. Women have represented 33.17% of the membership of the Village Works 
Road  Coordination  Committee  against  the  target  of  33%;  and  38%  of  building  groups  against 
the  target  of  40%.  The  current  project  risks  have  been  successfully  managed  through 
awareness raising, information dissemination, social mobilization, intensive on-site supervision, 
and  capacity  building  at  central  and  local  levels.  As  of  30  June  2011,  the  current  project’s 
overall physical progress was estimated by ADB’s Nepal Resident Mission at  90% against the 
elapsed  loan  period  of  95%.  As  of  5  July  2011,  the  cumulative  contract  award  was  $39.44 
million  and  disbursement  was  $27.51  million.  Considering  the  withdrawal  applications  in  the 
process  and  expenditures  already  incurred  by  districts,  the  current  project  is  expected  to 
complete all the remaining works by the loan closing date of 31 October 2011. 
 
11. 
The  scaled  up  project  scope  under  additional  financing  will  address  many  lessons 
learned from implementing past and ongoing rural roads projects, including the current project. 
These  include  undertaking  an  innovative  road  maintenance  program,  improving  the  access  of 
the rural  poor  to microfinance,  strongly  promoting the  use  of  building groups, restructuring the 
targeted skills training, and sharpening the focus on national and district capacity. The current 
project has established a satisfactory operating modality between central agencies and district 
administrations,  as  well  as  between  different  stakeholders  at  central  and  district  levels.  The 
current  project  has  prepared  and  designed  a  pipeline  of  additional  rural  road  subprojects  for 
implementation.  The  provision  of  additional  financing  for  the  current  project  will  build  on  this 
established pipeline of road subprojects to move rapidly toward implementation. There are very 
clear  efficiency  gains  to  be  realized  for  scaling  up  the  current  project  by  using  additional 
financing, especially in terms of being able to implement the subprojects already designed and 
to  utilize  the  structures  and  staffing  developed  in  the  current  project,  at  both  the  central  and 
district levels. 
 
B. 
 
12. 
The impact of the overall project will be reduced rural poverty in 18 poor and remote hill 
and  mountain  districts.  The  overall  project  outcome  will  be  widened  access  to  social  services 
and economic opportunities. 
 
C. 
 
The  overall  project  outcome  will  be  achieved  through  the  following  overall  project 
13. 
outputs: (i) rural livelihood improved, (ii) capacity and decentralized local governance enhanced,

1. 

Output 1: Rural Livelihood Improved  

 
14. 
The  scaled  up  project  scope  will  improve  community  infrastructure  in  the  18  districts. 
This  will  include  90  school  buildings  and  health  posts,  36  foot  or  mule  or  link  trails,  54  water 
supply  and  irrigation  schemes,  10  micro-hydropower  schemes,  8  rural  market  places,  10 
ropeways,  and  other  community  infrastructure. These  investments  are capped  at  $120,000,  or 
20%  of  the  cost  of  the  road  subproject,  whichever  is  lower.  Community  infrastructure12 will  be 
based on the demand and identified priorities in the impact zones of the road subprojects. The 
beneficiaries  of  the  community  infrastructure  are  expected  to  be  at  least  50%  women  and 
members of excluded groups.  
 
15. 
 The scaled up project will organize training that can contribute to a level 1 certification 
by  the  Nepal  Skills  Testing  Board;  and  will  provide  livelihood-related  skills  training  to  3,000 
beneficiaries from the project impact zones, of which at least 40% are women and 60% are from 
poor  and  excluded  groups.  The  social  awareness-raising  training  will  be  provided  to  9,000 
persons, of whom 80% are women, poor, and from excluded groups. The focus of awareness-
raising  training  will  be  on  good  nutrition,  health  and  sanitation  concerns  in  poor  rural 
populations. In nine pilot districts, it will work with existing savings and credit groups, and assist 
building  groups  willing  to  form  themselves  into  formal  savings  and  credit  cooperatives  and 
facilitate their access to credit from existing institutional suppliers. 
 

2. 

Output  2:  Capacity  Building  and  Decentralized  Local  Governance 
Enhanced 

 
16. 
The  scaled  up  project  scope  will  improve  district  and  national  capacity  building  to 
promote improved decentralized governance. The thrust will be on establishing the capacity for 
sustainable management of rural road networks, strengthening the decentralized management 
of  rural  infrastructure,  and  raising  central  capacity  to  support  local  government  bodies.  It  will 
provide  a  variety  of  training  to  strengthen  local  rural  road  planning,  construction,  and 
maintenance  management  capacity;  and  sustainable  financing.  At  the  national  level,  it  will 
improve  the  technical  and  management  capacities  of  the  Department  of  Local  Infrastructure 
Development and Agricultural Roads (DOLIDAR) by providing transport, training, and resources 
to  draw  on  specialized  services  from  the  consultants  and  nongovernment  organizations. 
Regional study tours will be designed and undertaken to enhance the learning experiences. 

Output 3: Rural Transport Infrastructure Extended and Maintained 

 
3. 
 
The  scaled  up  project  scope  will  improve  260  km  of  rural  roads  in  the  18  districts 
17. 
(200 km new and 60 km upgrading).13 The design phase of subprojects will consider the impact 
of  climate change,  which includes  avoiding  unstable  slopes,  high-risk soil  erosion-prone  areas 
and  landslide  areas,  and  waterlogged  areas near  streams;  strictly  implementing  slope stability 
measures  and  robust  road  drainage  systems;  graveling  the  road  in  high-risk  areas;  and  using 
better maintenance approaches. Rural roads of 1,200 km will be maintained in the 18 districts 
and 6,500 m of trail bridges will be constructed. The implementation of the road subprojects will

will be promoted over construction by contractors.  
 
18. 
The scaled up project scope  will provide direct support to road maintenance programs 
in  line  with  the  pilot  program  being  supported  by  development  partners  toward  a  sector-wide 
approach for maintenance of rural roads throughout the country. To qualify for the maintenance 
grant,14 the districts will clearly allocate the road maintenance function to a suitable person such 
as  the  district  maintenance  officer  in  the  district  technical  office,  prepare  an  inventory  of  all 
district  roads,  conduct  annual  road  condition  surveys,  and  prepare  annual  road  maintenance 
plans.  Routine  maintenance  will  be  delivered  by  the  length-persons,  creating  jobs  in  the 
districts. 15  A  system  of  toll  collection  will  be  piloted  in  nine  districts  to  augment  road 
maintenance funds.

SDR11,475,000  ($18  million  equivalent)  and  a  grant  of  $7  million  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds

finance the transportation and insurance costs of the project. The financing plan is in Table 2.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Governance 

Economic and Financial 

 
A. 
 
The economic viability of the overall project was assessed through a detailed analysis of 
24. 
three sample subprojects—Bajura, Solukhumbu and Taplejung districts—which are considered 
to  be  representative  of  the  types  of  rural  infrastructure  subprojects  to  be  financed  under  the 
overall project. The length of the roads ranges from 7.7 km for the Bajura road to 21.8 km for 
the  Taplejung road.  All  of  the  roads  were  assessed  to  be  appropriately  designed to  represent 
the least-cost approach to providing improved transportation. Economic benefits were assessed 
both  in  terms  of  consumer  surplus  through  reduced  costs  for  existing  and  incremental 
transportation  of  people  and  goods,  and  producer  surplus  in  terms  of  reduced  costs  of 
agricultural  production  and  incremental  production.16 The  analyses  of  the  sample  subprojects 
indicated that the economic internal rate of return is 15.3% for Bajura, 22.0% for Solukhumbu, 
and 22.7% for Taplejung. The sensitivity tests and risk analysis confirm that the subprojects are 
extremely  robust.  Distribution  analyses  confirm  that  the  overall  project  will  provide  substantial 
benefits to the poor. 
 
B. 
 
Project-specific governance risks have been analyzed by carrying out a governance risk 
25. 
assessment. A thorough assessment of the financial management and procurement capacities 
of the MLD and DOLIDAR was undertaken, and a set of realistic risk mitigation measures has 
been proposed and discussed with the government. Risks associated with project management, 
including  procurement  and  disbursement,  will  be  mitigated  by  (i)  providing consulting inputs to 
advise  and  assist  in  the  procurement  of  goods  and  services;  (ii)  requiring  that  civil  work 
contracts  include  a  condition  that  contractors  adhere  to  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as 
amended  to  date);  (iii)  the  PCU  periodically  inspecting  the  contractor’s  fund  withdrawals  and 
settlements; and (iv) reporting on project activities and implementation on the website to foster 
transparency  and  timely  awarding  of  contracts.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  was  explained  to 
and  discussed  with  the  government  and  DOLIDAR.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM.17 
 
C. 
 
26. 
The  scaled  up  project  scope  will  create  an  additional  4.7  million  person-days  of  jobs, 
from road improvement, maintenance, and the development of community infrastructure. About 
900,000–1,500,000  people  (of  which  65%  are  poor)  will  directly  benefit  from  the  project.  The 
poor—estimated  at  about  500,000–1,000,000  and  mostly  from  excluded  castes  and  ethnic 
groups  such  as  dalits,  Janajatis,  and  indigenous  peoples—will  be  targeted  for  participation  in 
building  groups,  complementary  investment,  and  access  to  microfinance,  awareness  raising, 
and  capacity  building  and  focused  livelihood  enhancement  schemes.  A  Gender  Equality  and 
Social  Inclusion  Action  Plan18 has  been  prepared  for  the  project  to  address  gender  inequality 
and  social  exclusion  issues.  The  Gender  Equality  and  Social  Inclusion  Action  Plan  contains 
specific targets for the participation of, and ensuring project benefits reach, poor rural women, 
and excluded groups in the subproject areas.

 Safeguards 

D. 
 
 27.  Environment.  The  overall  project  is  category  B  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  executing  agency  and  implementing  agencies  prepared  initial 
environmental  examinations,  including  environmental  management  plans  (EMPs),  for  the 
sample  subprojects.  The  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  was  revised  in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. The framework sets out the requirements 
for  project  screening  and  classification,  subproject  selection,  information  disclosure  to,  and 
consultation  with,  the  affected  people,  environmental  assessment,  EMP  development  and 
implementation, and monitoring and reporting. The initial environmental examinations found the 
planned  subprojects  to  have  only  small  and  localized  adverse  impacts  on  the  environment, 
which can be managed by the mitigation measures proposed in the EMPs. 
 
28. 
Resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples.  The  overall  project  is  category  B  for 
involuntary  resettlement  and  category  B  for  indigenous  peoples,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  Most  subprojects  involve  land  acquisition  and  involuntary 
resettlement,  but  the  involuntary  resettlement  impact  is  not  considered  significant.  The 
resettlement  framework  has  been  revised  and  updated  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy  Statement.  The  resettlement  framework  includes  a  due  diligence  procedure  to  ensure 
those donating land will not be impoverished through donation. Any donation will be confirmed 
through  a  written  record,  including  a  no-coercion  clause  verified  by  an  independent  external 
party.  Land  owners  not  conforming  to  the  donation  eligibility  criteria  will  be  offered 
compensation  at replacement  cost  and/or  assistance  so that  they  maintain  the  same or  better 
income  and  livelihood  status.  All  subprojects  will  be  screened  early  in  the  project  cycle.  If  a 
subproject involves any  involuntary resettlement impacts, an appropriate resettlement plan will 
be prepared based on the detailed design, disclosed to those affected persons, and submitted 
for  ADB  approval  in  accordance  with  the  resettlement  framework.  The  indigenous  peoples 
planning  framework  has  also  been  revised  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement,  with  special  assistance  measures  for  indigenous  peoples  and  other  vulnerable 
groups. Considering the nature and scale of the subprojects, any negative impact on indigenous 
peoples is expected to be limited to a few involuntary resettlements and land acquisition cases. 
In  addition,  a  gender  equality  and  social  inclusion  plan  contains  specific  actions  favorable  to 
indigenous peoples.
